image.altText: An image from above looking down at a boy carrying a blue bucket, walking across cracked dry land.

props.synopsis: The UN agency's annual State of the Global Climate report confirmed it wasn't just the hottest year on record, ocean heat reached its highest level since records began, global mean sea level also reached a record high and Antarctic sea ice reached a record low.

title.children: 'Off the charts' 2023 broke every single climate indicator, with record temperatures, ocean heat and sea level rise

image.altText: A close up of braille dots on a bus stop

props.synopsis: Public transport timetables and updates will soon need to be provided in accessible formats and taxi ranks will be required to increase the ratio of wheelchair accessible taxi spaces.

title.children: Public transport has been 'failing' millions of Australians. It's hoped these new rules could change that

image.altText: Image of a beach sign at beach on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: The woman, believed to be in her 40s, was found unconscious in the water at Pebbly Beach after attempting to rescue her daughter.

title.children: Mother drowns on NSW South Coast beach after trying to save daughter

image.altText: Jodie Robertson (right) wearing grey and Kurtis Hickey in a white shirt

props.synopsis: A 29-year-old man is charged following a neighbourhood dispute in Western Sydney where two people were hit by a car and injured in what police described as "a horrible scene".

title.children: Sydney couple seriously injured after being hit by SUV following dogs dispute, police say

image.altText: A young fair man wearing a chain on the beach

props.synopsis: Bradley Balzan was shot in his backyard after he walked away from four plain-clothed officers in Sydney's west in December 2020.

title.children: 'It's ruined two entire families': Final day of inquest into police shooting victim hears impact on loved ones

image.altText: Composite image of John Brumby and Dan Andrews.

props.synopsis: Members of Victoria's Labor government either refuse to speak to 7.30 about their multi-billion-dollar venture capital fund or don't know enough about its investments to answer questions as state debt skyrockets.

title.children: Victoria is $126 billion in debt and now the state's big venture capital gamble is looking questionable

image.altText: Emergency workers climb through building rubble.

props.synopsis: Some 9,000 children in Russia's Belgorod region could be moved away from the Ukraine border amid increasing civilian causalities, regional governor says.

title.children: Russian border region plans to evacuate thousands of children as new head of navy revealed

image.altText: Journalists and photographers stand around in protective gear as a fire rages in terraces during a protest

props.synopsis: The move is the latest in a series of developments widely seen as a sweeping political crackdown triggered by pro-democracy protests in 2019.

title.children: Hong Kong's legislature passes new national security law granting greater power to quash dissent

image.altText: A video screenshot showing Labor MP Anne Aly standing with a group of activists.

props.synopsis: Pressure is building on the Labor government over its stance on Gaza, with Labor minister Anne Aly confronted by pro-Palestinian activists who attended a constituent meeting on the weekend and new polling showing the extent of community anger.

title.children: 'Will you call it a genocide?': Police step in as protesters clash with Labor minister

image.altText: RBA governor Michele Bullock questioned on inflation

props.synopsis: The Reserve Bank has left interest rates on hold amid signs that growth in the economy has dramatically slowed down. Some economists have pushed out their forecasts for rate cuts to November, as RBA Governor Michele Bullock explains why it's too soon to cut rates.

title.children: RBA governor says there's no strong evidence to cut rates yet after another hold

image.altText: A ceiling inside a classroom with mould growth.

props.synopsis: A public high school in Broken Hill will be torn down and completely rebuilt after a severe mould infestation, possibly spread through the air conditioning system, was discovered by a staff member in January.

title.children: Broken Hill high school to be torn down and rebuilt after mould infestation

image.altText: A group of protesters holding climate change signs

props.synopsis: A pair of climate protesters who blocked traffic on Melbourne's West Gate Bridge for hours earlier this month have lost an appeal to reduce their sentences.

title.children: West Gate Bridge protesters who caused traffic chaos in Melbourne jailed for two months

image.altText: A close up of the princess smiling. She wears a bright red blazer and her brown hair is in a low bun

props.synopsis: Despite the increasingly wild theories about the whereabouts of Catherine, Princess of Wales, the reality is she appears in good enough health to pop down to her local shops.

title.children: 'Incredibly, woman goes to shop is breaking news': The reaction to Kate's pop to the shops

image.altText: Trees looking sick and are dying

props.synopsis: The word "poisoned" stamped onto the trunks of dying Norfolk pines along Botany Bay leaves passers-by in no doubt about the cause of their demise. If the aim was to improve views, it may backfire, as council's policy is to replace any destroyed tree with two more.

title.children: Balmoral Beach figs expected to survive as more waterfront trees vandalised in Sydney's south

image.altText: Hands holding a power bill

props.synopsis: There's no nationwide cap on electricity prices in Australia — instead, they're set by a hodgepodge of regulators and state governments. Here's how to make sense of them.

title.children: A state-by-state breakdown of possible changes to power price caps

image.altText: Jetsam on beach

props.synopsis: Witnesses say the boat was ditched by its occupants, who managed to get ashore safely on a tender, as they were attempting to cross the Clarence River bar near Yamba.

title.children: Pristine beach 'like a rubbish dump' after abandoned boat pulverised by surf on NSW north coast

image.altText: Tennis player Aryna Sabalenka and partner Konstantin Koltsov on a beach.

props.synopsis: Russian ice hockey club Salavat Yulaev says coach Konstantin Koltsov has died aged 42. Koltsov was the partner of world number two tennis player Aryna Sabalenka.

title.children: Partner of Australian Open champion Aryna Sabalenka dies aged 42

image.altText: A batsman walks off after a Cricket World Cup match, as the opposing team stand on the pitch.

props.synopsis: After cancelling an ODI series against Afghanistan last year, Cricket Australia calls off a T20 series on government advice "that conditions for women and girls in Afghanistan are getting worse".

title.children: 'Conditions for women in Afghanistan are getting worse': Cricket Australia cancels another Afghanistan series

image.altText: crossbench2

props.synopsis: Labor minister Don Farrell has accused teal independents of hypocrisy over election reforms after the crossbench accused the government of a "political stitch-up".

title.children: Teals 'agree with banning big money, just not theirs' — government minister

image.altText: Helicopter flying with fire ant bait

props.synopsis: Helicopters are being used in northern New South Wales as part of a $600 million program to stamp out red imported fire ants, after nests were detected south of the Queensland border late last year.

title.children: By land and by air, baiting program combats fire ant incursion in northern New South Wales

image.altText: Rosa Ellen, with black shirt and blue pants, and shoulder-length blonde hair, stands in an office looking at a phone screen.

props.synopsis: Since January Rosa Ellen has been living without a smartphone. Instead, she uses an old-fashioned, internet-free phone. It's brought unexpected hurdles, but she's found clever ways to manage them.

title.children: When Rosa ditched her smartphone for a 'dumb phone', unexpected challenges arose. Here's how she overcame them

image.altText: Picture of a high-voltage transmission line

props.synopsis: Benchmark electricity prices are set to fall for hundreds of thousands of customers but will rise for others under changes flagged by the country's energy regulator.

title.children: Belated power price relief for some, while other Australians expected to have increased bills

image.altText: A young white woman with blonde hair sitting on a couch with a baby with red hair

props.synopsis: Women say they are being routinely delayed or denied epidurals when giving birth because of mistaken beliefs about their impact on labour.

title.children: 'I felt violated': Samantha asked for an epidural three times during labour and was dismissed each time

image.altText: Uber logo seen on the outside of a building

props.synopsis: When Uber burst into the Australian market more than a decade ago, it came with all guns blazing. As it forks out almost $272 million, what happens next for the platform experts say "flouted the law"?

title.children: Uber 'flouted the law' for years, say experts. Now a compensation lawsuit means the 'cowboy company' is paying the price

image.altText: Oscar Piastri, sitting in his F1 garage, looking up and off into the distancem with a neutral expression.

props.synopsis: The Australian has happy memories of Albert Park, securing his first F1 championship points during last year's race in Melbourne.

title.children: Piastri expecting 'awesome atmosphere' in Melbourne as McLaren chase podiums

image.altText: South Sydney Rabbitohs' Latrell Mitchell, seen from the side, speaks into a Fox Sports microphone after an NRL game.

props.synopsis: NRL boss Andrew Abdo says the decision not to sanction Latrell Mitchell for swearing in a live radio interview "is consistent with how we've dealt players before".

title.children: Latrell urges people to 'move on' from swearing controversy as NRL boss rejects suggestion of special treatment

image.altText: Close up of a Tasmania Police cap.

props.synopsis: Tasmania Police say in line with a "commitment to accountability" it is releasing information relating to child sexual abuse allegations made against officers and reveals between 2000 to 2022, four were guilty of child sexual offences — all committed while serving.

title.children: Four Tasmania Police officers guilty of child sexual offences — all committed while serving

image.altText: Ukraine's Ambassador to Australia Vasyl Myroshnychenko at the Womadelaide music festival.

props.synopsis: Ukraine's ambassador says a documentary aired by the ABC uncritically repeated Russian propaganda and he will seek an explanation from the national broadcaster about why it was aired.

title.children: Ukraine's ambassador blasts ABC for airing 'bowl of vomit' documentary on Russian invasion

image.altText: Vladimir Putin resting his chin on his hand

props.synopsis: The Russian president's reign is set to continue for another six years, but his country faces numerous challenges, including a declining population, a devastating invasion of Ukraine and increasing international isolation, writes Riley Stuart.

title.children: With another term secured, Putin will continue his war in Ukraine. But he may be gearing up for another battle

image.altText: BYD cars in a showroom

props.synopsis: Two rival Japanese car makers have announced they will work together on electric vehicles, countering the rise of Chinese competitors.

title.children: 'Chinese brands a decade ahead of the rest': The reality facing the EV industry

image.altText: Nuclear power station chimneys

props.synopsis: The argument for re-examining the merits of nuclear power in Australia has been countered with concerns about the high cost of building the plants. But the rising price of uranium is another issue — and Australia's place as a major supplier doesn't guarantee cheap power, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Why corporate Australia won't touch nuclear power

image.altText: Willow's swollen leg after her allergic reaction

props.synopsis: Chloe sent her toddler to daycare confident they could manage her allergies. The child instead ended up in a West Australian hospital at risk of losing her ability to walk.

title.children: Toddler with severe dairy allergy taken to hospital after being fed chocolate cake at WA daycare

image.altText: Midnight Oil at the Royal Antler Hotel, Narrabeen, NSW, circa 1971.

props.synopsis: A TV show, radio station and smoke-filled pubs: Peter Garrett explains what drove Australia's rock revolution.

title.children: Midnight Oil never appeared on Countdown. But Peter Garrett says the show changed the band's trajectory
